channel.title: Tomato router firmware
channel.description:
I guess this belongs in linux because its based off linux.
I upgraded from stock linksys firmware to tomato firmware, boosted the x-mit power, and found an empty channel. The problem is, the wireless quality is worse than it was when I had the linksys firmware (poor signal, less than 24mbps connection). With the linksys firmware, I usually had a good/excellent signal with a 48mbps - 54mbps connection. This same thing happened to me with dd-wrt.
Anyone know how to fix this?

item.title: Tomato router firmware
item.dc:creator: @vbcoderx vbcoderx
item.description:
@vbcoderx wrote:

I have DD-WRT v23 SP1 Final micro installed on my router and I love it. Its so much better than that old shitty linksys firmware (I had to reboot the router to make ANY changes with that shit >.<). The only problem I have run into with it is that if I overclock the cpu above a certain level, the router reboots itself between midnight and 1 am… Not really a problem, just a nuisance if i’m doing something…

Read full topic

item.title: Tomato router firmware
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

It should be better if you didn’t change any settings. Try restoring dd-wrt to factory defaults and see if it is better.

Read full topic

item.title: Tomato router firmware
item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:
@chrisn2323 wrote:

but it worked just fine with linksys firmware, this shouldnt be any different.

Read full topic

item.title: Tomato router firmware
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:4, topic:295848”][quote author=T4_ link=topic=391875.msg2918301#msg2918301 date=1250608827]
Retire an older machine into a router (just put gigabit network cards in) and boot from m0n0wall cd. Obviously, place the cable from your modem/old router into eth0 (to make it simple), and a cable going out (eth1) to a switch. Then from the switch buy an access point and use the remaining ports on the switch to rout the wired machines. If you are using the old router -> new router, set up the new router as a DMZ on the old (obviously).
[/quote]

That doesn’t do anything to address his wireless signal problems though.

What did you boost the xmit to? Try not boosting it at all, I always run dd-wrt and find it much better than the stock linksys or netgear firmware.[/quote]
He could move it closer if it were a weak signal.

Read full topic

item.title: Tomato router firmware
item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:
@chrisn2323 wrote:

I boosted the xmit to 70mW

Read full topic

item.title: Tomato router firmware
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

T4_:

Retire an older machine into a router (just put gigabit network cards in) and boot from m0n0wall cd. Obviously, place the cable from your modem/old router into eth0 (to make it simple), and a cable going out (eth1) to a switch. Then from the switch buy an access point and use the remaining ports on the switch to rout the wired machines. If you are using the old router -> new router, set up the new router as a DMZ on the old (obviously).

That doesn’t do anything to address his wireless signal problems though.

What did you boost the xmit to? Try not boosting it at all, I always run dd-wrt and find it much better than the stock linksys or netgear firmware.

Read full topic
